title: Adaptation of the Spalax galili transcriptome to hypoxia may underlie the complex phenotype featuring longevity and cancer resistance
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
          <jats:p>In the subterranean rodent <jats:italic>(Nanno)spalax galili</jats:italic>, evolutionary adaptation to hypoxia is correlated with longevity and tumor resistance. Adapted gene-regulatory networks of <jats:italic>Spalax</jats:italic> might pinpoint strategies to maintain health in humans. Comparing liver, kidney and spleen transcriptome data from <jats:italic>Spalax</jats:italic> and rat at hypoxia and normoxia, we identified differentially expressed gene pathways common to multiple organs in both species. Body-wide interspecies differences affected processes like cell death, antioxidant defense, DNA repair, energy metabolism, immune response and angiogenesis, which may play a crucial role in <jats:italic>Spalax</jats:italic>‚Äôs adaptation to environmental hypoxia. In all organs, transcription of genes for genome stability maintenance and DNA repair was elevated in <jats:italic>Spalax</jats:italic> versus rat, accompanied by lower expression of aerobic energy metabolism and proinflammatory genes. These transcriptomic changes might account for the extraordinary lifespan of <jats:italic>Spalax</jats:italic> and its cancer resistance. The identified gene networks present candidates for further investigating the molecular basis underlying the complex <jats:italic>Spalax</jats:italic> phenotype.</jats:p>
caption:
üß¨‚ú® Discover the secrets of longevity and cancer resistance in the fascinating Spalax galili, a subterranean rodent with extraordinary adaptations! üå±üî¨ By comparing gene expression between Spalax and rats under different oxygen conditions, researchers have uncovered unique pathways that enhance DNA repair, antioxidant defense, and immune response. These adaptations help Spalax thrive in low-oxygen environments, contributing to its impressive lifespan and tumor resistance. üåøüß†

This groundbreaking research offers potential insights into human health, revealing strategies for maintaining genome stability and reducing inflammation. As we explore these gene networks, we edge closer to understanding the molecular basis of healthy aging. üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüîç

Let's celebrate the wonders of nature and the possibilities they hold for our future! üåü #Longevity #CancerResearch #Neuroscience #Spalax #GeneExpression #HealthyAging #ScienceInnovation

images.title: File:Fphar-04-00028-g001.jpg
images.author: Hiba Zahreddine Katherine L. B. Borden
images.description: FIGURE 1. A MAJOR IMPEDIMENT IN THE TREATMENT OF CANCER IS THE DEVELOPMENT OF RESISTANCE. While most tumors initially respond to the given therapy, the majority will relapse following treatment, and in some cases resistance even predates clinical intervention. Therefore cancer resistance can be classified in to two broad classes: primary or acquired. In both cases, the emergence of resistant cells could be due to, at least, two mechanisms: (A) presence of multiple initial clones some of which emerge as dominant after treatment. These subpopulations could possess stem-like characteristics and/or use their interactions with the surrounding microenvironment to enter into a dormant state, thus surviving the insult of therapy. (B) Acquisition of stochastic alterations within the cancer cells per se. In all cases, the surviving population is less likely to respond to any further therapy and will be responsible for the minimal residual disease and cancer relapse. The biochemical underpinnings of resistance include: alterations to drug metabolism, increased drug efflux, decreased drug uptake, modification of the drug targets, amplification of targeted protein, genetic rewiring, enhanced DNA repair, inactivation of apoptotic proteins, or activation of anti-apoptotic ones, among others.

title: An epigenetic clock for Xenopus tropicalis
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
          <jats:p>DNA methylation clocks have been widely used for accurate age prediction, but most studies have been carried out on mammals. Here we present an epigenetic clock for the aquatic frog <jats:italic>Xenopus tropicalis</jats:italic>, a widely used model organism in developmental biology and genomics. To construct the clock, we collected DNA methylation data from 192 frogs using targeted bisulfite sequencing at genomic regions containing CpG sites previously shown to have age-associated methylation in <jats:italic>Xenopus</jats:italic>. We found highly positively and negatively age-correlated CpGs are enriched in heterochromatic regions marked with H4K20me3 and H3K9me3. Positively age-correlated CpGs are enriched in bivalent chromatin and gene bodies with H3K36me3, and tend to be proximal to lowly expressed genes. These epigenetic features of aging are similar to those found in mammals, suggesting evolutionary conservation of epigenetic aging mechanisms. Our clock enables future aging biology experiments that leverage the unique properties of amphibians.</jats:p>
caption:
üß¨ Exciting news in the world of neuroscience! Researchers have developed an epigenetic clock for the frog species *Xenopus tropicalis*. This breakthrough uses DNA methylation to predict age, a technique previously applied mainly to mammals. The study reveals that age-related methylation patterns in these frogs share similarities with mammals, highlighting evolutionary conservation across species. This innovative tool opens up new possibilities for aging research, especially in amphibians, and could accelerate studies on aging interventions. üåøüî¨

Understanding these mechanisms is crucial for future research in developmental biology and genomics. By leveraging the unique properties of amphibians, scientists can explore new dimensions in aging biology. This could lead to insights into age-related diseases and longevity, making it a significant advancement in the field. 

Stay tuned for more updates on how this could revolutionize our understanding of aging! üåü

#Neuroscience #AgingResearch #Epigenetics #XenopusTropicalis #ScienceInnovation #BiologyBreakthroughs

images.title: File:CpG methylation in mouse development.png
images.author: Heather¬†J. Lee, Timothy¬†A. Hore, Wolf Reik
images.description: Global CpG Methylation Levels in the Mouse Germline, Somatic Tissues, and ESCs. The mouse germline undergoes two major waves of demethylation, the first in the early embryo where the paternal genome (blue) is actively demethylated prior to and during replication. Both the paternal and maternal (red) genomes passively lose methylation after this until the blastocyst stage (E3.5). The second wave of demethylation occurs in the primordial germ cells between E6.5 and E13.5 as they emerge from the epiblast. Methylation is then re-established in a sex-specific manner after E13.5 and the nongrowing (NG) oocyte stage, in males and females, respectively, eventually giving rise to mature gametic patterns. Naive and primed ESCs can be cultured from the ICM or be interchanged with each other (dashed line), by growth in either serum or 2i media, respectively. Only naive ESCs display low methylation (c. 30%) that corresponds to in vivo pluripotent tissues (shaded boxes on the far right). Erased cells display less than 10% methylation, whereas somatic tissues (derived from the E6.5 epiblast) show consistently high methylation around 70%‚Äì85%. The placenta is relatively demethylated compared to somatic tissues and is derived from the blastocyst trophectoderm (E3.5). In order to compare between genome-wide (Ficz et al., 2013; Hon et al., 2013; Kobayashi et al., 2012; Seisenberger et al., 2012; Shirane et al., 2013) and reduced representation bisulfite sequencing data sets (Smallwood et al., 2011; Smith et al., 2012), 100 kb probes not overlapping CpG islands were analyzed as previously (Ficz et al., 2013).
images.credit: (2014). "Reprogramming the Methylome: Erasing Memory and Creating Diversity". Cell Stem Cell 14 (6): 710-719. DOI:10.1016/j.stem.2014.05.008.

title: LinAge2: providing actionable insights and benchmarking with epigenetic clocks
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
          <jats:p>Biological aging is marked by a decline in resilience at the cellular and systemic levels, driving an exponential increase in mortality risk. Here, we evaluate several clinical and epigenetic clocks for their ability to predict mortality, demonstrating that clocks trained on survival and functional aging outperform those trained on chronological age. We present an enhanced clinical clock that predicts mortality more accurately and provides actionable insights for guiding personalized interventions. These findings highlight the potential of mortality-predicting clocks to inform clinical decision-making and promote strategies for healthy longevity.</jats:p>
caption:
üîç Discover the future of personalized health with LinAge2! This groundbreaking study explores enhanced biological aging clocks that predict mortality more accurately than traditional chronological age markers. üï∞Ô∏è By focusing on survival and functional aging, these clocks offer actionable insights for personalized interventions, paving the way for healthier, longer lives. üå±

In the world of neuroscience, understanding biological aging is crucial as it impacts cognitive decline and neurodegenerative diseases. LinAge2's advancements could lead to early detection and targeted strategies to maintain brain health as we age. üß†‚ú®

Embrace the potential of epigenetic clocks and their role in revolutionizing clinical decision-making and promoting longevity. #Aging #Neuroscience #Longevity #HealthInnovation #Epigenetics #HealthyAging

title: The role of inhibitory and excitatory neurometabolites in age-related differences in action selection
caption:
üß†‚ú® Aging gracefully involves more than just physical changes‚Äîour brains adapt too! Recent research highlights how neurometabolites, like GABA and glutamate, play a crucial role in action selection as we age. By using magnetic resonance spectroscopy, scientists observed that older adults show different patterns of neurochemical activity during tasks requiring quick decision-making compared to younger individuals. This study reveals that while both young and older adults experience changes in neurometabolites, these changes impact their task performance differently. Understanding these shifts can help improve cognitive and motor functions as we age, enhancing quality of life. 

Stay curious about the brain's incredible adaptability! üåü #Neuroscience #Aging #BrainHealth #CognitiveFunction #Neuroplasticity

title: Predicting all-cause mortality with machine learning among Brazilians aged 50 and over: results from The Brazilian Longitudinal Study of Ageing (ELSI-Brazil)
caption:
üîç Exciting advancements in neuroscience and aging! A recent study from Brazil has harnessed the power of machine learning to predict all-cause mortality among those aged 50 and over. By analyzing data from over 9,000 participants, researchers identified key predictors like age, sex, BMI, medication use, and physical activity. The Random Forest algorithm stood out with an impressive AUC of 0.92, showcasing its potential in transforming healthcare for aging populations. üåü Integrating these insights into healthcare systems could revolutionize policy planning and targeted interventions, paving the way for healthier, longer lives. 

Stay tuned as we explore how technology continues to shape the future of health and aging. üí°

#Neuroscience #MachineLearning #HealthyAging #Innovation #Brazil #HealthTech

images.title: File:Relative risk and 95% CI of all cause-mortality associated with 25 g per day increase in olive oil consumption.jpg
images.author: Authors of the study:     Miguel A. Mart√≠nez-Gonz√°lez     Carmen Say√≥n-Orea     Vanessa Bull√≥n-Vela     Maira Bes-Rastrollo     Fernando Rodr√≠guez-Artalejo     Mar√≠a Jos√© Yusta-Boyo     Marta Garc√≠a-Solano
images.description:
"Abbreviations: RR, relative risk; CI, confidence interval; RCT: randomized controlled trial. Buckland G, 2012: Cancer mortality = a. Donat-Vargas C, 2021: ENRICA Study = c. ‚àóThese 5 studies did not quantify the consumption of olive oil in g/d and we assumed 25 g/d as the difference between extreme categories. When these 5 studies were removed, the RR for the subgroup of cohort studies assessing all-cause mortality was 0.87 (0.81‚Äì0.93) and the overall RR was 0.87 (0.82‚Äì0.93)."

"A 16% reduced risk of CVD (relative risk [RR]: 0.84; 95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.76 to 0.94), standardized for every additional olive oil consumption of 25 g/d was found. No significant association with cancer risk was observed (RR: 0.94; 95% CI: 0.86 to 1.03, per 25 g/d). Olive oil consumption was associated with a 22% lower relative risk of T2D (RR: 0.78; 95% CI: 0.69 to 0.87, per 25 g/d) without evidence of heterogeneity. Similarly, it was inversely associated with all-cause mortality (RR: 0.89; 95% CI: 0.85 to 0.93, per 25 g/d). Only the results for T2D were homogeneous. Specific sources of heterogeneity for the other 3 outcomes were not always apparent."

"Exploratory meta-regression analyses were conducted using the ‚Äúmetareg‚Äù command. Covariates explored in the meta-regression analyses were geographical origin (Mediterranean and non-Mediterranean countries), number of participants (<10,000 vs ‚â• 10,000), length of the follow-up period (<10 vs ‚â• 10 years), exposure assessment (olive oil quantified vs olive oil in categories), mean intake of olive oil (‚â•12 g/d vs < 12 g/d)."

"A 16% reduced risk of CVD (relative risk [RR]: 0.84; 95% confidence interval [CI]: 0.76 to 0.94), standardized for every additional olive oil consumption of 25 g/d was found. No significant association with cancer risk was observed (RR: 0.94; 95% CI: 0.86 to 1.03, per 25 g/d). Olive oil consumption was associated with a 22% lower relative risk of T2D (RR: 0.78; 95% CI: 0.69 to 0.87, per 25 g/d) without evidence of heterogeneity. Similarly, it was inversely associated with all-cause mortality (RR: 0.89; 95% CI: 0.85 to 0.93, per 25 g/d). Only the results for T2D were homogeneous. Specific sources of heterogeneity for the other 3 outcomes were not always apparent."

"Exploratory meta-regression analyses were conducted using the ‚Äúmetareg‚Äù command. Covariates explored in the meta-regression analyses were geographical origin (Mediterranean and non-Mediterranean countries), number of participants (<10,000 vs ‚â• 10,000), length of the follow-up period (<10 vs ‚â• 10 years), exposure assessment (olive oil quantified vs olive oil in categories), mean intake of olive oil (‚â•12 g/d vs < 12 g/d)."
